_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Secondary Smelting and Alloying of Aluminum

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
TST Inc. is a secondary aluminum smelting operation located at 11601 Etiwanda St. in Fontana, CA.  The facility uses chlorine to react with contaminants in molten metal baths so that the contaminants can be removed.  Chlorine is the only CalARP (19 CCR) and RMP (40 CFR) regulated material on site.  Chlorine is considered a toxic gas for the purposes of the regulations.

Chlorine is stored in the form of a gas liquified under pressure.  It is stored in two stationary storage tanks with a total maximum storage capacity of  71,000 pounds together.  From these tanks, it is converted to a gas and fed at approximately 40 psi via piping to production areas on the property.

The site's accidental release prevention policy is accomplished by implementing measures as required by CalARP, 40 CFR, and California's Process Safety Management (PSM) rules.  Preventive maintenance, inspections and employee training are considered critical.  The site maintains a prevention program at the RMP program 3 level.  This includes the following elements:  process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating and mechanical integrity procedures, training, management of change, pre-startup review, compliance audits, incident investigation, employee participation,contractor safety, and hot work permits.  Each of these elements consists of written procedures, policies, and practices that are maintained in order to ensure the integrity and safety of the chlorine system.

Accidental releases are mitigated, and emergency response is facilitated, primarily through the use of chlroine sensors throughout the facility.  The sensors trigger an alarm so that proper actions can be taken.   In some cases, the sensors also trigger a system shutdown.

The facility's policy on emergency response is that actions will be taken only to render immediate assistance to an injured employee, or to correct small problems within the job scope and capabilities of available trained staff.  The site does not forma

llly maintain PPE to respond to catastrophic releases, and will depend on outside responders for large emergencies and public notifications.  Because it does not have an RMP-defined Emergency Response Plan to handle catastrophic releases, the Emergency Response section of the RMP*Submit document is left blank.  However, the site maintains a written emergency response program to meet other OSHA-based requirements.  That document covers chlorine and other emergencies that might occur.  The facility also has a Business Plan and Hazardous Materials Inventory, which is transmitted to the primary emergency responder (San Bernardino County Fire Department.)  Employees were last trained on the site's Emergency Response program in May 2011.
